nodes.title: ðŸ”§ Remove AQB package
nodes.body:
- The aqb package is used to build ArangoDB quries without using the query language (AQL).
- This package is deprecated and was last updated 2015.
- It also does not support important commands for graph traversal like "inbound"/"outbound"
- replace by standard AQL.

nodes.title: âœ¨ Architectural Redesign
nodes.body:
Each visualization should be implemented as plugin, similar to [apache/superset](https://github.com/apache/superset).
Following proposed structure, similar to [plugins](https://github.com/apache/superset/tree/master/superset-frontend/plugins)
* Frontend & Backend should be split into two parts
    * e.g. frontend: `binocular-frontend`
    * e.g. backend (indexing part) `binocular`
* each visualization should be located in `<frontend-root>/plugins/<visualization-name>`
    * each visualization is its own "project", i.e. has its own `package.json`
    * `binocular-frontend` uses the visualization in the `package.json` in the "dependencies" section
        * e.g. `"@superset-ui/plugin-chart-echarts": "file:./plugins/plugin-chart-echarts"`
* Can the backend indexers also be structured in a similar way to be more efficiently extendable?
    * Or even replaceable? I.e. to replace the current node implementation with e.g. rust/python/wasm/etc. without much restructuring
    * What is necessary for this step? How does e.g. models need to be defined to be universally useable?

nodes.title: âœ¨ Frontend Redesign
nodes.body: Possible ideas might be taken from [gizual.com](https://gizual.com).

nodes.title: Improve Docker image building
nodes.body: Continuing the work of #152

nodes.title: ðŸ§© Binocular as Docker Image
nodes.body:
- Publish fully functional image
- Publish minimal image
- Publish arangodb image with test data

nodes.title: ðŸ§© Containerization
nodes.body: Binocular should be possible to run in a container which should be automatically generated with a pipeline.

nodes.title: âœ¨ Configurable Indexing though config file
nodes.body:
Not everyone needs every kind of data so it should be possible to specify in the config file which data should be indexed and which not through a whitelist or blacklist.

Proposed idea for CLI:
* `binocular` should be the command, as it is right now
* `binocular index` should execute the indexing process
    * Here it should be possible to provide a config file and/or provide config arguments
    * e.g. Enable/Disable offline building
    * Enable/Disable CI, ITS, etc
* `binocular webserver` should only execute the backend, no indexing in this case
    * For this, the frontend must run on another port which then accesses the backend
* Allow indexer to use a `ignore` section in the config file to exclude certain files and folder from indexing
    * e.g. sometimes, especially in education, `node_modules` is committed, which might break indexing binocular in memory-/space-limited environments. In such cases, it should be possible to exclude the committed folder from indexing
    * We check, per default, for files like this ```git log --name-status -- '*.db' '*.log' '*/.idea' '*.iml' '*node_modules*' '*target*' '*dist*' '*.DS_Store*' '*__MACOSX*'```, hence we could consider already adding these in the config file as an example

nodes.title: âž•Adding Screenshots to Docs
nodes.body: There should be screenshots in the docs to give users a preview without having to launch binocular.

nodes.title: Auto-versioning with NPM and Git
nodes.body: See https://javascript.plainenglish.io/auto-versioning-with-npm-and-git-786c6795b926

nodes.title: Ignore files at index time
nodes.body:
- add field to `.binocularrc` that causes the backend to ignore specified files/directories during indexing
- allow the use of wildcards

nodes.title: âž•CLI Export Command
nodes.body: There should be a proper way to export databases through the binocular cli by providing a command that just exports a db. As options, it should be possible to select the db that you want to export and where to export as default it should export the db of the repo where binocular gets executed and into the folder it gets executed. it would be also good to have a command to list all the available databases that can be exported.

nodes.title: ðŸ”§ remove deleted branches from database
nodes.body:
If a remote branch is deleted, it stays in the local database.
Remove these branches (and their connections) from the database at index time.

nodes.title: ðŸ› Bugs in Dashboard Visualizations
nodes.body:
- changes visualization:
  - Stacked area chart sometimes has gaps, does not display data correctly
  - in standalone mode (not as part of the dashboard), universal time settings have no effect (same with issues, CI)
- time spent visualization:
  - Overall amount of spent time varies depending on granularity setting
  - Stacked area chart sometimes has gaps, does not display data correctly

nodes.title: ðŸ› Dockerfile installation bug
nodes.body:
The Backend Dockerfile has a bug with the installation of Binocular with linux

```
# Error: Cannot find module @rollup/rollup-linux-x64-musl.
    # npm has a bug related to optional dependencies (https://github.com/npm/cli/issues/4828).
    # Please try `npm i` again after removing both package-lock.json and node_modules directory.
```

nodes.title: ðŸ› Visualizations crash when clearing DateTime
nodes.body: When you open the date range selector in the universal settings and clear the dateTime some visualizations crash and you can only fix it by reloading the page and press the reset button of the date Range filter fast enough or by clearing the local storage-

ðŸ”§Improve Local Storage
nodes.body: The current implementation of the local storage, especially for the universal settings does not behave as expected if the author list changed from the last time binocular was executed. Maybe also include a local storage version so that it's easier to recognize with which version of Binocular the local storage was created so that it can be initialized when the version changes.

nodes.title: âž•Disable VCS Indexer in CLI
nodes.body: Currently, it's possible to disable the ITS and CI indexer in the CLI. It should be also possible to disable the VCS indexer.

nodes.title: Ownership documentation, improvements
nodes.body:
- Add documentation for ownership database connection
- reduce size of ownership connection in database
- improve offline performance of ownership-related database functions

nodes.title: ðŸŽ¨ Convert all Backend Models to TS Classes
nodes.body:
Currently, all db models in the backend are defined in the old commonjs syntax that typescript cant handle that well. It would be good if all of those get converted to ts classes.

This most likely requires a rewrite of the model.js file because the current implementation is not really compatible with ts. the model.define method should also be removed so that every model can just extend the default model class.

nodes.title: âœ¨ Stakeholders Collection Redesign
nodes.body:
Overhaul the way Binocular indexes users.
- [x] Rename `Stakeholders` to `Users`. These represent the actual git users that commit to the repository.
- [x] Introduce `Accounts`. These are profiles on platforms like GitHub or GitLab, which are used for e.g. issue tracking.
- [x] Avoid redundant information in the database by splitting objects: E.g. accounts that are assigned to an issue are not stored in the issue object, but are represented by an `issues-accounts` connection.
- [x] Uniformly store ITS data, no matter from which platform it comes.
- [x] Add tests for ITS indexers.

nodes.title: âœ¨ Offline Launch Performance
nodes.body:
Improve launch performance of offline build.
- defer expensive database operations to web worker
- minify offline build
- reduce size of embedded JSON files that are used to fill pouchDB

nodes.title: Code Changes per Issue Label Visualization
âœ¨ Commit History
nodes.body:
- So far, every time commits are queried, we calculate the history of each commit and add a string of all previous commit hashes to the commit object. That means each object has a string with all sha hashes back to the first commit stored.
- The in-memory objects are therefore very large

Tasks:
- [x] replace this by on-demand history calculation for single commits
- [x] rewrite visualizations so they do not rely on having the histories of all commits per default

nodes.body: additional Unit Tests for indexers, db functions

nodes.title: Errors while running npm run dev when project path has spaces
nodes.body:
As written in the title I get errors, specifically multiple times the errors:
`stderr: /bin/sh: line 1: cd: too many arguments`
and
`stderr: /bin/sh: line 1: cd: too many arguments` 
if one of the directories in the path where project binocular is located has spaces.
I fixed the error by moving the directory with the project to a path which doesn't have spaces, but it is good practice and it would make the application more user friendly if users could store and run the project in a path that has directories with spaces.

nodes.title: â™»ï¸ convert CI Indexer to TS

nodes.body: GitHub CI and ITS indexers parse URL incorrectly if the repo was cloned via SSH.

nodes.title: Test Coverage Awareness Visualization
nodes.body:
1. Anzahl der testbezogenen Commits im Zeitverlauf:
**Visualisierung:** Liniendiagramm oder Balkendiagramm, das die Anzahl der Commits zeigt, die Ã„nderungen an Testdateien im Zeitverlauf beinhalten.
**Erkenntnis:** Dies kann helfen, die HÃ¤ufigkeit und Konsistenz von Test-Updates zu verstehen und Perioden intensiver Tests oder deren Mangel zu erkennen.

2. Beitragende zu Testdateien:
**Visualisierung:** Kreisdiagramm oder Balkendiagramm, das die Verteilung der BeitrÃ¤ge zu Testdateien unter verschiedenen Beitragenden zeigt.
**Erkenntnis:** Dies hilft zu identifizieren, welche Entwickler am meisten zu den Tests beitragen und ob die Testverantwortlichkeiten gleichmÃ¤ÃŸig verteilt sind.

3. Wachstum der Testdateien im Zeitverlauf:
**Visualisierung:** Liniendiagramm, das das Wachstum der Anzahl der Testdateien oder der Gesamtzeilen von Code in Testdateien im Zeitverlauf zeigt.
**Erkenntnis:** Dies kann zeigen, wie sich die Testsuite erweitert und ob sie mit dem Wachstum des Codebestands Schritt hÃ¤lt.

4. HÃ¤ufigkeit der Ã„nderungen an Testdateien:
**Visualisierung:** Heatmap, die die HÃ¤ufigkeit von Ã„nderungen an Testdateien zeigt, mÃ¶glicherweise segmentiert nach Tag oder Woche.
**Erkenntnis:** Dies kann Muster aufdecken, wann Tests am hÃ¤ufigsten aktualisiert werden, z. B. als Reaktion auf Fehlerbehebungen oder neue Funktionsrollouts.

5. Testabdeckung von Codebereichen:
**Visualisierung:** Wenn Testdateien so strukturiert sind, dass sie bestimmten Bereichen des Codebestands entsprechen, kann eine Baumkarte oder ein Sunburst-Diagramm verwendet werden, um zu visualisieren, wie verschiedene Bereiche des Codes durch Tests abgedeckt werden.
**Erkenntnis:** Diese Visualisierung kann hervorheben, welche Teile des Codebestands gut getestet sind und welche mÃ¶glicherweise eine ausreichende Testabdeckung vermissen lassen.

This only applies to the Data Plugins that support live refresh. If the refresh happens automatically should be selectable in the settings.

nodes.title: Sum of commits overall
nodes.body:
# Sum of commits

- Show the total sum of commits by each committer in the repo
- Graphically do this by using a column chart
- Change parameters for further insights
- Show combination of data of the involved committers

# Goal

- Support the evaluators by gaining insights of each committers participation
- Get first overview of the work-input by commits
- Create room for discussions about possible collaboration work (i.e. CodeWithMe by JetBrains)/ need for help

nodes.title: ðŸ› (New Frontend) Fix Dashboard
nodes.body: Currently, if anything on the dashboard is changed all components re-render. This behavior should be changed so that only the affected component re-renders. The amount of rows in the dashboard should also dynamically scale and not be fixed.

nodes.title: Collaboration Graph
nodes.body:
## Collaboration Graph
- Show the developers of a project and their connections
- visualize this by displaying the developers as nodes and their connections as edges between them
- allow grouping and highlighting of collaborators by amount of connections
- collaboration parameter is set to be: assignees on the same issue
## Goal
- Provide an overview of team-structure/dynamic to aid in spotting (in)-frequent collaborators and groups
- Enable developers to enhance team cohesion and possibly plan pair-programming/ collaborative sessions to combat shortcomings or improve on strengths

nodes.title: Developer Expertise Score
nodes.body:
# Konzept
Ein Developer Expertise Score System fÃ¼r Binocular wÃ¼rde das Wissen jedes Entwicklers in
verschiedenen Teilen der Codebasis quantifizieren und visualisieren. Dieses System wÃ¼rde
die durch den MSR-Prozess gewonnenen Informationen nutzen, um jedem Developer nach
seinem Wissen Ã¼ber die Codebase einzustufen. Dies kann verschiedene Anwendungen finden
wie zum Beispiel bei der Zuweisung von Code-Reviews, Einarbeitungsprozessen und anderen
Aufgaben.

# Faktoren
Zur Berechnung eines Scores kÃ¶nnen die aus Software-Repositories gewonnenen Statistiken
wie Commits, geÃ¤nderte Dateien, Code-Ownership und andere Faktoren genutzt werden.
Folgende wissenschaftliche Arbeiten haben dieses Thema erforscht:
-  T. Fritz, J. Ou, G. C. Murphy, and E. Murphy-Hill, "A degree-of-knowledge model
to capture source code familiarity," 2010 ACM/IEEE 32nd International Confer-
ence on Software Engineering, Cape Town, South Africa, 2010, pp. 385-394, doi:
10.1145/1806799.1806856.
- A. Mockus and J. D. Herbsleb, "Expertise Browser: a quantitative approach to iden-
tifying expertise," Proceedings of the 24th International Conference on Software
Engineering. ICSE 2002, Orlando, FL, USA, 2002, pp. 503-512.
- F. Rahman and P. Devanbu, "Ownership, experience, and defects: a fine-grained study
of authorship," 2011 33rd International Conference on Software Engineering (ICSE),
Honolulu, HI, USA, 2011, pp. 491-500, doi: 10.1145/1985793.1985860.

# Visualisierung
Mit dem berechneten Score kÃ¶nnen verschiedene AnsÃ¤tze zur Visualisierung dieser Daten
verwendet werden.
- Knowledge-Heatmap fÃ¼r verschiedene Dateien (Radar)
- Pie Chart fÃ¼r projektweite Verteilung

nodes.title: âœ¨ (New Frontend) Port Code Ownership Visualization
nodes.body: Also Improve Performance if possible

nodes.title: Change frequency map
nodes.body: In this visualisation I would use a scatter plot to represent the frequency of changes in different files/modules. The X-axis would show the average number of additions + deletions per commit, while the Y-axis would show the number of commits per file/module. Each data point in this graph would represent a single file/module. This type of visualisation could help identify for example the most volatile files (in the top right corner).

nodes.title: Commit Visualization by File
nodes.body:
# The Issue
- It can be hard to easily identify the scope of a given commit
    - Where are the main changes?
    - What has been changed?

# The SolutionÂ 
- Visualise file changes per commit
    - Grouped by package/folder
    - Visual cues for the amount (number of lines altered) and nature (lines deleted or added) of the changes

# Scope
- Retrieve data per file for the given commit from the database
- Parse and display this data in the frontend
- Evaluate the solution according to the research questions

# Non-Scope
- Which part of the file has been altered

# Mockup

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6fa09b26-0cc0-4821-aa5d-ed77ad058ebe)

nodes.title: âœ¨ (New Frontend) Add option, which add previous period baseline to cumulative charts
nodes.body:
Currently, charts (e.g., Time Spent) always start at zero for the selected period, regardless of data from earlier periods.
Enhance the logic to calculate and include the cumulative value from the previous period as the starting baseline. This will make the chart appear continuous over time and more accurately represent cumulative totals.

Do not load everything and filter afterwards for all use cases.
